RMP Executive Summary 2022

Introduction:
This Risk Management Plan (RMP) has been prepared for the AMVAC Chemical Corporation's pesticide manufacturing facility at 12650 Highway 43 North in Axis, Alabama. The plant manufactures pesticides which require the handling of Acutely Hazardous Materials in quantities which make them subject to the RMP requirements of the Clean Air Act. AMVAC's Risk Management Plan is prepared in accordance with the RMP Rule 40 CFR 68. The AMVAC Axis facility has a North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) code of 32532 for Pesticide and Agricultural Chemical Manufacturing. The AMVAC RMP must be revised and resubmitted every five years.

Please note that the K500/ K550/ Tokuthion process has been out of operation since 2019 and therefore a PHA has not been performed since 09/30/2019. Before restarting the process, a new PHA or PHA update/ renew will be performed. PSSR, training, and operating procedure reviews will also be followed before reinstating K500/ K550/ Tokuthion operation.

Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy:
AMVAC is committed to operating and managing the facility in keeping with applicable regulations and good operating practices. AMVAC has implemented operating practices in its endeavors to minimize the risk of an accidental release of a regulated substance. If an incident were to occur, AMVAC has preparedness measures in place to respond appropriately and minimize the release impact. 

Stationary Source and regulated substances handled:
The AMVAC Axis facility was originally a portion of the FMC (Formerly Dupont) Mobile Manufacturing Center. It was purchased from Dupont by AMVAC on May 18, 2001. The AMVAC Axis facility and the FMC (Formerly Dupont) facility are on a common site. The AMVAC facility consists of various buildings, chemical process vessels, above ground storage tanks, truck loading/unloading stations, railcar loading/unloading stations, and various ancillary equipment.

Th

e AMVAC Axis facility has a NAICS Code of 32532 for Pesticide and Agricultural Chemical Manufacturing. The following listed substances are subject to the RMP requirements:

Listed Toxic Substances:
1. Chlorine, CAS # 7782-50-5 
2. Phosphorus Trichloride (PCL3), CAS # 7719-12-2
3. Bromine, CAS# 7726-95-6 
4. Carbon Disulfide (CS2), CAS # 75-15-0 

Listed Flammable Substances:
1. Methylamine (MMA), CAS # 74-89-5
2. Isopropylamine (MIPA), CAS # 75-31-0

As listed in the RMP, chlorine and phosphorus trichloride are chemicals associated with multiple covered processes. These covered processes are run as batch processes and operate using some of the same tanks, equipment, etc during different campaigns. The covered processes that utilize the same tanks/ equipment are unable to be in operation at the same time. As such, maximum quantities of chlorine and phosphorus trichloride are the same for each of their applicable processes and not additive when determining the maximum quantities for the site.
 
AMVAC'S MISSION STATEMENT

AMVAC Chemical Corporation (AMVAC) is committed to:
- Providing its customers with sustainable environmentally responsible, cost-effective and high-quality products on time.
- Providing a safe, healthy and secure working environment for its employees.
- To operate in a manner which meets or exceeds existing laws and regulations and reflects the high level of concern and respect for the local community.
- Investing in its future through aggressive research and development of new innovative products and markets.
- Providing its investors with higher than normal returns.

SAFETY FIRST POLICY

One of Amvac's missions is to provide a safe and secure environment for its employees while maintaining a high level of concern and respect for the community.  To accomplish this mission, it is necessary for Amvac to maintain safe conditions at all of its facilities and to prevent a release of any kind to the environment. Every employee's fi

rst priority is to be responsible for safety and full environmental regulatory compliance. Whenever an employee identifies any unsafe condition, occupational safety and health risk, or environmental risk, the employee must report the matter immediately to his supervisor if he is unable to remedy the situation himself.  If the supervisor is unavailable, the employee must immediately inform the Plant Manager, Operations Manager or Manager on duty of the situation so that the condition can immediately be corrected.  Any and all unsafe conditions must be corrected immediately and notification of the supervisor is required in a timely manner.  Employees need not fear any form of reprisal as the result of their compliance with this policy.  Amvac will not tolerate any reprisals towards an employee who reports non-compliance to this policy.  

Worst-Case and Alternative Case Release Scenario for covered toxic substances:
The site-specific worst-case and alternative case release scenario for covered toxic substances is on file at the covered facility.

Worst-Case and Alternative Case Release Scenario for covered flammable substances:
The site-specific worst-case and alternative case release scenario for covered flammable substances is on file at the covered facility.

AMVAC's Release Prevention Program:

Process Safety Information 40 CFR 68.65 - AMVAC has a written Process Safety Information (PSI) procedure that outlines how process safety information is maintained for all covered processes. It is AMVAC's policy to make PSI accessible to all affected employees in accordance with site Confidentiality Agreement requirements. Safety Data Sheets (SDS) are maintained at the AMVAC Axis site for regulated substances involved in covered processes. AMVAC must document that equipment complies with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.

Process Hazard Analysis 40 CFR 68.67 - AMVAC's Process Hazard Analysis procedure includes methods used for complyi

ng with requirements. AMVAC utilizes computer software to document PHAs. Process hazard analysis (hazard evaluation) must be conducted on covered processes. The process hazard analysis (PHA) must be updated and revalidated, based on their completion date. It is the responsibility of the process safety manager to determine the appropriate Process Hazard Analysis methodology to be used. AMVAC promptly addresses PHA recommendations based upon the risk factors associated with the scenarios being addressed.

Operating procedures 40 CFR 68.69 - AMVAC maintains written operating procedures that provide instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process. AMVAC operating procedures describe tasks to be performed, data to be recorded, operating conditions to be maintained, samples to be collected, and safety and health precautions to be taken. AMVAC procedures are technically accurate, understandable to employees, and revised periodically to ensure that they reflect current operations. Operating procedures are readily accessible to employees who work in a process.
Operating procedures are reviewed to ensure that they reflect current operating practices. AMVAC must certify annually that these operating procedures are current and accurate. AMVAC has developed and implemented safe work practices such as lockout/tagout; confined space entry; opening process equipment or piping; and control over entrance into a stationary source by maintenance, contractor, laboratory, or other support personnel.

Training 40 CFR 68.71 - Each employee involved in operating a covered process is trained in an overview of the process and in operating procedures. Refresher training is provided at least every three years. Training documentation ascertains that each employee involved in operating a process has received and understood the training. Training records include the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the means used to verify that the employee un

derstood the training.

Mechanical integrity 40 CFR 68.73 - The purpose of the Amvac Chemical Axis Plant Mechanical Integrity Program is to assure the continued integrity and operability of process equipment to support safe, reliable, and cost-effective operation. As part of Amvac Chemical's commitment to safe operation, the Mechanical Integrity Program is managed and performed in a way that protects employees, the public, and the environment. The program addresses special requirements of OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals. 

The following components make up the Mechanical Integrity program at AMVAC:
?	maintenance procedures
?	training and performance of maintenance personnel
?	quality control measures
?	equipment tests and inspections
?	good engineering practices

Management of change 40 CFR 68.75 - AMVAC maintains a written Management of Change (MOC) procedure to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures; and changes to stationary sources that affect a covered process. All changes are detailed and authorized in the electronic Management of Change database. When the change is complete and before it is put into operation or use, the appropriate parts of the electronic MOC form will be signed to show that all the required elements of process safety management have been completed. In addition, for new plant and where plant has been modified, a Pre-Startup Safety review will be done.

Pre-startup review 40 CFR 68.77 - Pre-startup reviews are performed for new sources and for modified sources when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information. AMVAC has developed a Pre-Startup Safety Review procedure.

Compliance audits 40 CFR 68.79 - AMVAC evaluates compliance with the provisions of this regulation at least every three years to verify that procedures and practices developed are adequate and are being followed.

Incident investigatio

n 40 CFR 68.81 - AMVAC is required to investigate each incident which resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. The incident investigation must be initiated no later than 48 hours following the incident. Incident report findings and recommendations are promptly addressed and are resolved and documented. The incident report is reviewed with all affected personnel whose job tasks are relevant to the incident findings. These requirements are addressed in the AMVAC Incident Reporting procedure. 

Employee participation 40 CFR 68.83 - AMVAC has developed a written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation required by this regulation. AMVAC consults with employees on the conduct and development of PHAs and on the development of the other elements of process safety management in this regulation. AMVAC's employee participation procedure ensures that the Axis site will follow a written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation for each of the listed PSM elements. 

Hot work permits 40 CFR 68.85 - Hot work permits must be issued for hot work operations on or near a covered process. The permit documents that the fire prevention and protection requirements in 29 CFR 1910.252(a) have been implemented prior to beginning hot work operations. It indicates the date authorized for hot work, and the identity of equipment being worked on. The permit must be kept on file until completion of the hot work operations.

AMVAC has developed a hot work and safe work permit procedure that addresses these requirements. It documents steps that have been taken in preparing the job so that it may be done in the safest possible way. It also details the safety procedures and protective equipment required on anticipated possible hazards.

Contractors 40 CFR 68.87 - When selecting a contractor, AMVAC must obtain and evaluate information regarding the contract owner's safety performan

ce and programs. AMVAC must inform the contractor of the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to the contractor's work and the process. AMVAC must explain to the contractor the applicable provisions of the AMVAC Emergency Response Plan. AMVAC must implement safe work practices to control the entrance, presence, and exit of the contractor in covered process areas. AMVAC must periodically evaluate the performance of the contractor in fulfilling their obligations of this regulation.

The contract owner or operator must assure that each contract employee is trained in the work practices necessary to safely perform his/her job. The contract owner or operator must assure that each contract employee is instructed in the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to his/her job and the process, and the applicable provisions of the emergency action plan. The contract owner or operator must document that each contract employee has received and understood the training required by this regulation. The contract owner or operator must prepare a record which contains the identity of the contract employee, the date of training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training. The contract owner or operator must assure that each contract employee follows the safety rules of AMVAC. The contract owner or operator must advise AMVAC of any unique hazards presented by the contract owner or operator's work, or of any hazards found by the contract owner or operator's work.

The Five-Year Accident History:
There have been no accidents involving acutely hazardous materials since the acquisition of the Axis plant by AMVAC.

AMVAC's Emergency Response Program:
AMVAC Chemical Corporation has adopted and implemented an Emergency Response Plan for the purpose of handling emergency situations in such a manner as to minimize the risks to life, environment, and property. Emergency Response is mutually shared and coord

inated by the emergency response teams from AMVAC and FMC. 

The Emergency Response Plan includes procedures for handling releases and spills of hazardous materials in any area and contains specific emergency procedures for bomb threat, firefighting, emergency alarm activation, evacuation, offsite emergencies, local area emergency notification, government agency notification and hurricanes. AMVAC conducts inspections of the facility and the equipment, and emergency response drills are conducted.

The Emergency Response Plan is reviewed annually and/or when:
a) There has been a major change in the facility chemicals and or plant operation that changes the potential for fires and the release of hazardous substance, such that a change in the response is needed for any emergency.
b) The plan fails in an emergency.
c) There is a change of emergency coordinator/responders.
d) There is a change of emergency equipment.

Any incident or emergency which results in a chemical release is reported to agencies as applicable. All incidents will be reviewed and investigated as to its cause and method for future prevention.

All plant personnel receive training on the implementation of the emergency response plan upon hire, upon changes in the plan, and periodic refresher training on the various aspects of the plan.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
AMVAC Axis currently has no additional detailed or defined plans for any changes such as installation of additional mitigation or control equipment, technology, organizational changes, etc. However, there
is an ongoing program that addresses all employee related issues and suggestions. AMVAC will continue to improve the safety performance accordingly.
